review.title: ICON Challenge on Algorithm Selection
review.abstract: We present the results of the ICON Challenge on Algorithm Selection.

metadata.title: ICON Challenge on Algorithm Selection

sections.text: ICON Algorithm Selection Challenge http: / / challenge.icon-fet.euLars Kotthoff16. November 2015

sections.heading: 1 Submissions
sections.text: Participants came from 4 different countries on 2 continents. Table 1 gives an overview of all submissions. All submissions were submitted for evaluation for all ASlib scenarios. Most systems used a pre-selection and specified a subset of features for each scenario.

sections.heading: 2 Evaluation
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it will happen, until it does.

sections.heading: 3 Results
sections.text: For comparison, we show three other systems. Autofolio-48 is identical to Autofolio, but 48 hours of training time has been given to assess the impact of additional research into hyperparameter space. Lama-regrPairs and Lama-regr are simple Lama models (see Appendix A. To assess how significant the difference is and how stable the ranking is, we have taken 1000 Bootstrap samples from the scenario split combinations and calculated the values and ranks on each of them. The mean of the total score averages over the Bootstrap samples and the confidence intervals are in Table 3.The ranking corresponds to the final ranking in Table 2. Confidence intervals show that the rankings are relatively stable.

sections.heading: 3.1 Winner – zilla
sections.text: The winner of the ICON Challenge on Algorithm Selection is Zilla by Chris Cameron, Alex Fre � chette, Holger Hoos, Frank Hutter and Kevin Leyton-Brown.

sections.heading: 3.2 Honourable mention – ASAP RF
sections.text: ASAP RF by Fran cois Gonard, Marc Schoenauer and Miche le Sebag receives an honourable mention as a submission that has not yet been described in the literature and showed a respectable performance that in some cases surpassed all other approaches.

sections.heading: 3.3 Alternative rank aggregations
sections.text: An alternative (and probably fairer) method of determining the winner is to consider the ranking of the systems generated by each measurement in each division of each scenario as a ballot (for a total of 260 ballots) and to aggregate the ranking in these ballots. At this point, we optimize the aggregated Spearman coefficient between candidate leaderboards and ballots. That is, the final ranking indicates the optimal Spearman coefficient in terms of ballots. However, there are significant changes when performance across all metrics, divisions and scenarios is averaged by the median, not by the mean. Table 5 shows this ranking. Zilla is now in second place, beaten by ASAP RF.

sections.heading: 3.4 Detailed results
sections.text: Tables 6 to 8 show the ranking order by mean for all splits and scenarios, but separately for each measurement. Table 9 shows the ranking order for the different scenarios for all systems by mean for all measurements and splits. Figures 1 to 3 give a more detailed overview of the performance of the systems for the different scenarios. The color of each box plot indicates the system whose mean performance is shown in the legend (this corresponds to the number in the respective table above). The box plots show the performance differences in the 10 different splits for each scenario. The solid black line indicates the performance of the individual best solver; everything about it is worrying.Two of the SAT scenarios are difficult for all systems in that the performance they deliver on at least one of the splits is worse than the performance of the individual best solver. In most other scenarios, the use of any algorithm selection system results in a significant improvement in performance compared to the individual best solver.

sections.heading: 3.5 Time required to run
sections.text: The time taken to train the models and make the predictions varied considerably between systems and scenarios, with some having to be completed within minutes and others within hours. Figure 4 is a summary.

sections.heading: 4 Acknowledgements
sections.text: We would like to thank all participants who took the time to prepare entries and help them get them up and running; in alphabetical order: Alex Fre � chette, Chris Cameron, David Bergdoll, Fabio Biselli, Fran cois Gonard, Frank Hutter, Holger Hoos, Jacopo Mauro, Kevin Leyton-Brown, Marc Schoenauer, Marius Lindauer, Miche le Sebag, Roberto Amadini, Tong Liu and Torsten Schaub. We would like to thank Barry Hurley for setting up and maintaining the submission website and Luc De Raedt, Siegfried Nijssen, Benjamin Negrevergne, Behrouz Babaki, Bernd Bischl and Marius Lindauer for their feedback on the design of the Challenge. All data, code and results of the Challenge are available at http: / / 4c. ucc.ie / ~ larsko / downloads / challenge.tar.gz.

metadata.abstractText: The evaluation was performed as follows. For each scenario, 10 bootstrap samplings of the entire data were used to create 10 different train/test splits. No stratification was used. The training part was left unmodified. For the test part, algorithm performances were set to 0 and runstatus to “ok” for all algorithms and all instances – the ASlib specification requires algorithm performance data to be part of a scenario. A cv.arff file was generated for both training and
